articles.title: Summer La Niña watch in place for only second time in 75 years
articles.summary: This summer will be wetter and windier than usual for some parts of New Zealand. La Niña will bring moist, rainy conditions to northeastern areas of the North Island and reduced rainfall to the lower and western South Island. The rest of the country has a chance of above-normal rainfall for the next three months.

articles.title: Here's how Trump changing the Gulf of Mexico's name would 'cause some confusion'
articles.author: WPTV
articles.summary: Donald Trump wants to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America. Mexico's president suggests renaming the body of water "América Mexicana" as Claudia Sheinbaum suggests. The Gulf is 930 miles wide and bordered by the United States and Mexico.

articles.title: Heat can make workers more susceptible to mental health issues
articles.author: Chin Hui Shan
articles.summary: As temperatures rise, workers in South-east Asia could be more susceptible to mental health issues, according to Dr Ken C. Shawa, a senior economist at the International Labour Organisation. He was speaking at the First Global Heat Health Information Network (GHHIN) South-East Asia Heat Health Forum, which is being held at Parkroyal on Beach Road from Jan 7 to 10.

articles.title: Trump could change the Gulf of Mexico's name if he wanted
articles.summary: Donald Trump's proposal to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico would have far-reaching implications, according to an associate professor of history at Florida Atlantic University, who is concerned about the implications for the U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's policy.

articles.title: Rare summer La Niña watch in place
articles.summary: This summer will be wetter and windier than usual for some parts of New Zealand. La Niña will bring moist, rainy conditions to northeastern areas of the North Island and reduced rainfall to the lower and western South Island. The rest of the country has a chance of above-normal rainfall for the next three months.

articles.title: School Delays And Closings Announced For St. Mary's, Charles, Calvert, Anne Arundel, And Prince George's Counties
articles.author: TBN News Coordinator – JB
articles.summary: Charles County public schools will open two hours late tomorrow, Thursday, January 9, 2025. St. Mary's County Public Schools will have a delayed opening of two hours. Anne Arundel County Public School will open 2 hours late on Thursday, Jan. 9. All Prince George's County Schools will be closed.

articles.title: Climate Conversations - Will Southeast Asia's digital rush come at a climate cost?
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Southeast Asia is one of the hottest markets for setting up new digital infrastructure. The modern-day gold rush of building data centres poses a huge climate challenge. Jack Board and Liling Tan give a ringside report on Climate Conversations with Jack Board.

articles.title: Cold weather causing delays for some schools around the cape fear
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Bladen County Schools will operate on a two-hour delay for Thursday. Whiteville City Schools will be open at 9:30 a.m. Wind chills are forecasted to be between 10-15 degrees for areas on Thursday morning, so some schools will start school later.

articles.title: Antarctic ice rebounds from record lows
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice extent has recovered to 7.3 million square kilometres by the end of 2024. This is close to the 1981 to 2010 average. Scientists have been concerned since mid-2016 that global warming could be setting in motion more lasting changes in how much sea ice forms in Antarctica.

articles.title: Weather: La Niña watch in place for the second time in 75 years
articles.summary: A change in air flow patterns means there will be mixed weather through to March. La Niña will bring moist, rainy conditions to northeastern areas of the North Island and reduced rainfall to the lower and western South Island. The rest of the country has a chance of above normal rainfall for the next three months. Warmer than average air and sea temperatures are likely for North Island. There are equal chances for near average or above average seasonal temperatures for the south Island.

articles.title: Extreme weather, suburban sprawl fuel LA's wildfires
articles.author: Issam AHMED
articles.summary: It's too soon to say how much climate change contributed to the Los Angeles wildfires. However, scientists agree that rising temperatures are making such fire-prone conditions more frequent. The UN Environment Programme report found a potential global increase in extreme fires by up to 14 percent by 2030 and 30 percent by 2050.

articles.title: Wildfires Rage in Los Angeles: A Climate Change Crisis
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The wind-driven wildfires sweeping across Los Angeles epitomize the climate-induced weather extremes scientists predict will worsen as global temperatures rise. The fierce wildfires erupted within hours of severe weather alerts, signaling heightened wind and dry heat warnings in Los Angeles. The National Weather Service issued red flag warnings amid a backdrop of dry fuels.

articles.title: Fast Facts: Wildfire trends in the US
articles.author: Alex Leeds Matthews
articles.summary: There are more wildfires in western states due to climate change and longer fire seasons. The number of houses within wildfire perimeters has doubled since 1990, according to a study by the U.S. Geological Survey.      .   in California.

articles.title: Can Donald Trump change the name of the Gulf of Mexico?
articles.summary: Donald Trump wants to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America. Can he do that? He needs to ask the people of America if he can do that. The people of the United States are sceptical about it.

articles.title: Urbanisation, change in land use making Shillong hotter: Study
articles.author: Our Reporter
articles.summary: Shillong is experiencing a rise in land surface temperature due to urbanisation and changes in land use and land cover. The study analysed Shillong's LULC and surface temperatures from 1993 to 2023. Settlement areas have expanded by 10.96% over the past 30 years, mainly at the expense of agricultural land, vegetation, and water bodies. The replacement of natural land with concrete and asphalt leads to less rainwater being absorbed into the ground and more flooding.

articles.title: Never Forget: THEY KNEW
articles.author: Haricot Blue
articles.summary: They let the planet burn for profit. They knew in 1959 that if the world kept using fossil fuels, the ice caps would begin to melt and sea levels would rise. In 1981 Exxon scientists were no longer questioning whether the buildup of CO2 would cause the world to heat up. Shell Oil produced a film called Climate of Concern to be shown in schools and universities in 1991.

articles.title: Farm, fisher jobs top employment decline
articles.author: Cai U. Ordinario
articles.summary: There were 1.99 million job losses in the Agriculture and Forestry sector, including 1.6 million jobs in elementary occupations such as farm laborers and fisherfolks. The Word Bank projects that the agriculture sector for the next 5 years is expected to grow by a percent or less. The government will expand its cash-for-work and training programs to reach climate-vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Climate change threatens well-being of youths. Here's how to help them cope
articles.author: Bernard Wolfson
articles.summary: Bernard Wolfson is worried about the future of the planet because of the extreme weather conditions on the planet. He is concerned that if we don't address the problem now as a society, the situation is going to get worse for the planet in the long run.

articles.title: There's Something A Little Scarier Than Zombie Viruses Frozen In Permafrost
articles.author: Riponk Riponk
articles.summary: The northern reaches of the planet are warming as much as four times faster than the global average. This is causing dormant microbes to rise after spending tens of thousands of years frozen in place. Scientists are more concerned about carbon than with 'zombie viruses'. Permafrost covers some 20 million square kilometres and contains an astonishing amount of carbon. If warming causes the release of just 1% of it, it could have a profound effect on the planet.

articles.title: Volunteer and advisory positions open in Lee and Charlotte counties
articles.author: WGCU Staff
articles.summary: Charlotte County Board of County Commissioners is looking for volunteers for the following appointments: Agricultural & Natural Resources Advisory Committee, Environmental Sensitive Lands Oversight Committee and MSBU/TU Advisory Boards. Sanibel City Council is accepting applications to fill one seat on the Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee.

articles.title: I'm Melting! Lexus GX SUVs allegedly suffer strange damage
articles.author: Toronto Sun
articles.summary: Some new Lexus SUVs in Arizona are showing unexplained heat damage to the side mirrors. It could be from the sun, as one Arizona owner claims.   Â. Â   “All this allegedly melting trim is from sun.

articles.title: Japanese Scientist: The IPCC's Climate Models Are Fundamentally Flawed, Use False Assumptions
articles.author: P Gosselin
articles.summary: There is no theoretical basis for the Net Zero policy based on the man-made climate change narrative of the IPCC. It comes from the lack in knowledge of the atmospheric window of the energy budget of the earth by modelers. All sky was adapted from Martin Wild, Climate Dynamics (2020) 55:553-577.

articles.title: No windmills, more rakes: Trump's archaic climate politics return
articles.author: Philip Bump
articles.summary: The mechanism for climate change is well established. Gases like carbon dioxide and methane sit in Earth's atmosphere and absorb heat rising from the planet. Some of that absorbed heat is redirected back down to the Earth's surface. We've dumped so much of those gases into the atmosphere by burning oil, coal and gas.

articles.title: 2025 will be a decisive year for the climate in a world 'more uncertain and tense than ever'
articles.author: Audrey Garric
articles.summary: The climate crisis continues to worsen and disasters are multiplying. 2024 is set to become the hottest year on record. The election of Donald Trump has sent shockwaves through climate diplomacy. Trump pledged to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement on his first day in office.

articles.title: How has 2024 fared in the climate record books?
articles.summary: Last year was New Zealand's 10th warmest year on record. Eight months of 2024 recorded above-average temperatures. March and May were the only two months that recorded below-average temperature. Auckland saw only 82 per cent of its normal rainfall in 2024. MetService meteorologist Mathapelo Makabulane expects temperatures to return to normal after this week.

articles.title: Centre says Goa failed to finalise CZMP plan over five years
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: Goa has failed to finalize its Coastal Zone Management Plan (CZMP) under the CRZ Notification of 2019. The revised CZMP would include stricter safeguards for Ecologically Sensitive Areas (ESAs) and more comprehensive regulatory measures, but until it is finalized, all development and regulatory activities in Goa are assessed under the older framework. The delay has persisted for nearly five years, with Goa missing multiple deadlines since the 2019 notification was issued. Goa has less than a month left to meet the January 2025 deadline.

articles.title: A climate researcher says the impacts of climate change are clear, with another year of above average temperatures
articles.summary: NIWA says New Zealand's temperature last year averaged about 13 degrees. It was the 10th warmest year on record. Victoria University of Wellington's James Renwick says our weather's becoming more differentiated, between east and west. He says the wet places are becoming wetter and the dry places dryer.

articles.title: We can't afford to take another five-year breather on climate action
articles.author: Fiona Ryan
articles.summary: It's looking likely that Australia will delay the announcement of its next big climate target - the 2035 emissions reduction goal. This shift could have serious consequences for the 1.5-degree global temperature goal and increase the costs of achieving it. UNEP has been clear that countries must enhance their 2030 and 2035 targets. Chris Bowen, the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, has requested the Climate Change Authority to provide advice on a 2035 target.

articles.title: We can't afford to take another five-year breather on climate action
articles.author: Fiona Ryan
articles.summary: UNEP's latest recommendations on NDCs say global emissions need to drop 42 per cent below 2019 levels by 2030 to stay on track. Australia's current goal - 42% below 2005 levels - translates to just 26 per cent reduction, which is too far off the mark.

articles.title: We can't afford to take another five-year breather on climate action
articles.author: Fiona Ryan
articles.summary: It's looking likely that Australia will delay the announcement of its next big climate target - the 2035 emissions reduction goal - amid the political uncertainty following Donald Trump's election.      .   "It is looking likely" that the announcement will be delayed.

articles.title: We can't afford to take another five-year breather on climate action
articles.author: Fiona Ryan
articles.summary: It's looking likely that Australia will delay the announcement of its next big climate target - the 2035 emissions reduction goal. UNEP argues that failing to strengthen the 2030 targets will make the 1.5-degree global temperature goal almost impossible. Chris Bowen, the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, has requested the Climate Change Authority to provide advice on a 2035 target.

articles.title: CDB Approves USD900K Grant to UWI to Strengthen Water & Climate Resilience in Jamaica
articles.summary: The Caribbean Development Bank has approved a grant of USD909,000 to The University of the West Indies to support efforts in strengthening water resource management and building climate resilience in Jamaica's coastal and inland communities. The project is being executed under CDB's Caribbean Action for Resilience Enhancement (CARE) Programme, which is funded by the European Union.

articles.title: Hawaii Climate Advisory Team Advocates for Bold Action with Policy
articles.author: Source
articles.summary: Hawaii Climate Advisory Team (CAT) has produced a policy paper with 14 recommendations for the administration's legal framework for the 2025 legislative session and beyond. The paper emphasizes the urgency of immediate and foundational policy-making. Hawaii's isolation, dated infrastructure, and disaster risks mandate an amplified focus on and investment in preparedness.

articles.title: Salamina residents battle fish farm expansion plans
articles.author: Yiannis Elafros
articles.summary: Plans to expand aquaculture operations off the coast of the Saronic island of Salamina have sparked widespread backlash. Residents, officials and local organizations warn the proposed expansion could irreparably degrade the island's environment. The Salamina Environmental Group has gathered 11,000 signatures opposing the plan.

articles.title: More than 100 hidden volcanoes could soon erupt in Antarctica
articles.author: Josh Milton
articles.summary: There are at least 100 volcanoes in Antarctica, but only two are active. The majority of volcanoes are subglacial, so they are not visible from the surface. The melting of the Antarctic ice sheet could trigger eruptions of the volcanoes. The research is important to understanding how the changing climate interacts with ancient volcanic systems.

articles.title: Cold Weather Shelter opening in Charlotte County Wednesday and Thursday nights
articles.author: ABC7 Staff
articles.summary: The Charlotte CARE Center will provide shelter to persons needing refuge from the cold on Wednesday and Thursday, Jan. 8 and Jan. 9 nights. Guests will need to pre-register by calling 941-627-4313 and arrive by 8 p.m.

articles.title: Five ways to make aviation more sustainable right now
articles.author: Iain Hanson
articles.summary: Aviation is a source of 2.5% of global CO2 emissions. It is predicted to grow at 4% per year for the foreseeable future. The industry needs to reduce its carbon footprint now. There are 575 existing or planned airport projects around the world at a total value of US$488 billion (£395 billion) in the next two decades.

articles.title: Toxic smoke from the L.A. fires is blanketing the region
articles.summary: Wildfires raging around Los Angeles mean air quality has plummeted. What's the risk for everyone breathing that air and how can people protect themselves? Copyright 2025 NPR. For more information, go to 2025 NPR's website here.    For more info on the Upper Great Lakes News, Music, and Arts & Culture, visit the website here:

articles.title: The case against a ‘climate emergency'
articles.author: Lionel Shriver
articles.summary: January is ideal month for gaining a sense of perspective. I'm convinced that the 'climate emergency' is another social mania we'll look back on with: "J-eez, what was that about?" The paradigm displays the classic anthropocentrism of our era.

articles.title: Cool Cabanas: How beach tent sparked turf war in Australia
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Hordes of shade covers have taken over Australian beaches, sparking a debate over the country's tanning laws. The phenomenon has sparked a debate about the state of the sunniness of the country.      Â   in Australia.

articles.title: NZ's top expats in Australia: Kiwis leading businesses across the Tasman
articles.author: Tom Raynel
articles.summary: There was a net migration loss of 30,000 people to Australia in the year ended March 2024. New Zealand's economy is in decline and more Kiwis are looking for better opportunities and higher pay in Australia. Those who have achieved success stand out at the top.

articles.title: Delhi's Weather: From Chilled Mornings to Sunny Afternoons
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: On Wednesday, Delhi transitioned from cold, foggy mornings to sunny afternoons as temperatures climbed to 21.5 degrees Celsius. The morning's minimum temperature saw a steep decline to 7.4 degrees Celsius, accentuating the cold start. The air quality deteriorated, moving from a 'poor' AQI of 287 at dawn to'very poor' at 334 by 9 am.

articles.title: The Norfolk village slowly crumbling into the sea: Dramatic photos taken 22 years apart lay bare the devastating impact of coastal erosion on Hemsby beach
articles.author: AIDAN RADNEDGE
articles.summary: Hemsby beach in Norfolk has been destroyed by strong winds and high tides. The coastal village has suffered from severe coastal erosion in recent years. Since 2013, the village has lost 25 houses, including in December 2023 when five homes south of the Gap were demolished following high tides and fierce winds.

articles.title: 2024 10th-warmest year on record: Niwa
articles.author: John Lewis
articles.summary: Niwa recorded New Zealand's 10th-warmest year on record in 2024. Eight of the 10 warmest years on record occurred since 2013. El Nino event in the equatorial Pacific brought more westerly and southwesterly winds than normal over New Zealand. It also brought several extreme rainfall events to the southern regions. Lumsden recorded its wettest year since records began in 1982.

articles.title: Why Greenland? The world's largest island plays a key role in climate change
articles.author: Fast Company
articles.summary: Greenland is remote, icy and mostly pristine. It plays an outsize role in the daily weather experienced by billions of people and in the climate changes taking shape all over the planet. It is central to the geopolitical, geoeconomic competition in many ways. It has scarce resources and is tense.

articles.title: A new financial keystone for climate action
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: South Africa has been hit hard by Climate Change. The projected tipping points are coming closer to reality. Wits Global Change Institute pegs three alarming tipping points – conditional on our actions.      .   "Tipping points" are predicted by scientists.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows: US scientists
articles.author: Knoxville Daily Sun
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice rebounded in December after a long period of record lows. The rate of sea ice loss during the warmer period had been near-record daily lows, according to US scientists. It gives pause to speculation that Earth's frozen continent could be undergoing a permanent change.

articles.title: How Innovative Disaster Risk Financing Can Help Africa Tackle Impacts Of Climate Change
articles.summary: IPCC report warns of more frequent and severe climate extremes in Africa due to climate change. Djibouti signed a multi-year, multi-peril insurance agreement with the World Bank, Descartes Insurance and the African Risk Capacity Group (ARC) for drought and excess precipitation.

articles.title: Scientists Found Astonishing Lost Landforms Hidden a Half-Mile Beneath the Sea
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: During the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), Earth adopted a 100,000-year glacial-interglacial cycle compared to the previous 41,000 year cycle. Scientists have discovered landforms created during the MPT as glaciers retreated across what is now the North Sea.

articles.title: Australian television star forced to evacuate home as monstrous fires rage across LA: 'Please pray for our neighbourhood
articles.author: Daily Mail
articles.summary: Australia's Next Top Model star Didier Cohen has been forced to evacuate his home in Los Angeles as fires rage across the city. He was forced to leave his home because of the fires.    Didier Cohen is a model from Australia's next top model series.

articles.title: A new financial keystone for climate action
articles.author: Opinion
articles.summary: South Africa has been hit hard by Climate Change. President Ramaphosa has decided to establish a Climate Change Response Fund. The CCRF will bring together all spheres of government and the private sector in a collaborative effort to build our resilience and respond to the impacts of climate change.

articles.title: Officials assess the path ahead for popular Erwin trail
articles.author: CARL RAPHAEL Correspondent
articles.summary: Three months after Hurricane Helene, Erwin continues to tally up the damage. The Erwin Linear Trail suffered a major hit from the flooding.       in Erwin, the area was hit hard by Helene's heavy rains.

articles.title: Meteorologist: BBC Article Falsely Blames 2024 Extreme Weather On Climate Change
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: BBC's article A Year of Extreme Weather That Challenged Billions presents a false narrative, attributing various weather events in 2024 directly to climate change. The World Meteorological Organization distinguishes between weather and climate. The IPCC reports low confidence in any long-term increases in tropical cyclones. Media outlets have a responsibility to present information accurately and without bias.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows: US scientists
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice extent recovered in December after a long period of record lows, US scientists say. This gives pause to speculation that Earth's frozen continent could be undergoing a permanent change due to climate change. Sea ice concentrations in Antarctica remain low over large areas of the pack.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows: US scientists
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice rebounded in December after a long period of record lows. The rate of sea ice loss during the warmer spring months of November and December slowed to well below average, the US National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) said on Tuesday.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice rebounds from record lows: US scientists
articles.author: Juan Barreto
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice had shrunk to record lows. Juan BARRETO is from Argentina and is an expert on Arctic sea ice. He is also a member of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange (BLOXDCE) and docafp.com.

articles.title: Melting Antarctic ice could trigger hidden volcanoes, intensifying climate change
articles.author: Madhyamam
articles.summary: As climate change accelerates the melting of Antarctica's vast ice sheet, scientists warn it could awaken over 100 hidden volcanoes buried beneath the frozen continent. This process is driven by the loss of pressure on underground magma, which is caused by the climate change.

articles.title: Economic, social, and environmental impacts of Trump's Whitehouse comeback
articles.author: PHIDEL KIZITO
articles.summary: Donald Trump is positioning himself for a return to the White House. African leaders and analysts are concerned about the impact of his policies on the continent. Trump's first term was marked by protectionist policies and an emphasis on reshaping trade agreements to benefit the U.S. He was criticized for rolling back environmental protections, withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement, and championing fossil fuel production. His stance on immigration and refugee resettlement emphasized national security concerns over humanitarian needs. His disinterest in international climate cooperation and focus on deregulation may further impede global efforts to tackle environmental threats.

articles.title: Trump says he will rename the Gulf of Mexico. Can he do that?
articles.author: Washington Post
articles.summary: Donald Trump wants to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America. European explorers and mapmakers have used the name 'Gulf of Mexico' for at least 400 years. There are existing mechanisms to rename places recognized by the federal government. If the name change becomes official, other nations will recognize it too.

articles.title: Mayor Woodby gives latest update as FEMA deadline reached
articles.summary: Carter County Mayor Patty Woodby's latest update on the continuing recovery from Hurricane Helene has reached a new stage. The deadline for filing with the Federal Emergency Management Agency and other federal organizations has been reached for filing the update with the FEMA and other agencies.

articles.title: Remote but resource-rich Greenland occupies key position in warming world
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: Greenland is remote, icy and mostly pristine. It plays an outsized role in the daily weather experienced by billions of people and in the climate changes taking shape all over the planet. It is central to the geopolitical, geoeconomic competition in many ways. It has scarce resources and is tense.

articles.title: Climate change impacts HIV prevention and care, study finds
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: New challenges in HIV prevention and care are emerging due to climate change, according to a review published in Current Opinions in Infectious Disease. Extreme weather events are associated with poorer HIV prevention outcomes, reduced HIV testing and increased practices that elevate HIV risk. The study also uncovered important implications for HIV care among those already living with HIV, such as reduced viral suppression and poorer treatment adherence.

articles.title: Last year becomes New Zealand's 10th-warmest year on record: NIWA
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: 2014 was New Zealand's 10th-warmest year on record. Eight of the 10 warmest years on record have occurred since 2013. The warming trend is consistent with human-caused climate change. There were extreme rainfall events and four local state of emergency declarations.

articles.title: AP Explains How Global Warming Could Be Causing More Cold Blasts
articles.author: Brett T.
articles.summary: According to the Associated Press, global warming could create more frequent cold blasts nationwide. Global cooling was the big topic in Scholastic Magazine when this editor was in middle school. The Associated Press reports that frigid air that normally stays trapped in the Arctic has escaped and is plunging deep into the United States.

articles.title: Politics state and national, and the Gulf of America: Down in Alabama
articles.author: Ike Morgan
articles.summary: Trump wants to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the 'Gulf of America' as his inauguration approaches. The Laken Riley Act would make it easier to arrest and hold undocumented theft suspects until they can be deported. State Sen. Rodger Smitherman's bill would require couples to take a conflict-resolution class before they get married. State Rep. Chip Woods' bill would increase penalties for making terrorist threats.

articles.title: Australia's beach 'cabana crisis': Fury over tourists erecting gazebos early in the morning to hog prime spots on the sand as PM Anthony Albanese wades into debate
articles.author: ED HOLT
articles.summary: The Prime Minister of Australia has waded into a debate over the use of portable gazebos to selfishly hog prime spots on the country's famous beaches. Anthony Albanese claims the practice is against the idea of Australia's egalitarian spirit. In recent years, portable beach cabanas have become increasingly popular in Australia.

articles.title: NC mountain counties altering school schedules on Wednesday
articles.author: QCN Digital Team
articles.summary: Some mountain county school districts are changing their schedules on Wednesday because of the weather. Ashe County is the same as Tuesday with remote learning starting at 10 a.m. in Avery County, schools will be in-person but on a three-hour delay in Watauga County.

articles.title: Addressing the gendered double burden of the climate crisis
articles.author: Suryaprabha Sadasivan
articles.summary: COP29 concluded with mixed outcomes. The issue of embedding gender-responsive strategies into climate actions remains a pressing challenge. Women in climate-vulnerable regions face a double burden: they are disproportionately affected by environmental changes and have increased social and economic responsibilities. The current flow of global climate finance barely scratches the surface. $3.2 trillion is required for health-related climate action to address the climate crisis's impact on public health.

articles.title: Warmer Ocean Temperatures Responsible for Unseasonably Mild January
articles.author: Sara Strickland
articles.summary: According to Chris St. Clare, warm ocean temperatures are the cause of the cold in Atlantic Canada. The contrast between warm and cold air can also cause unsettled weather, like the high winds and surf that pounded the east-facing coast lines last weekend. Chris is writing a book on the effects of changing climate across Canada and hopes to have it out this year.

articles.title: Cobourg's Jan. 8 forecast: Mainly sunny
articles.author: Torstar Open Data Team
articles.summary: This story was automatically generated using data from Environment and Climate Change Canada and has been automatically shared via Twitter, Facebook and other social media channels.   .      i   in this case, the article link has been copied and saved.

articles.title: Fact check: Antarctic sea ice extent comparison consistent with climate change
articles.author: Kate S. Petersen
articles.summary: The Instagram post claims that Antarctic sea ice area maps show climate change is a hoax. USA TODAY gives the post a false rating. Scientists have documented long-term changes in many climate systems across the globe to prove that Earth's climate is changing rapidly as a result of human activity.

articles.title: Why more Americans are dying from the cold
articles.author: Anna Phillips
articles.summary: There are more deaths related to cold weather in the United States due to climate change. A second winter storm in a week is forecast to pummel parts of the U.S. Experts warn that risk factors making people more susceptible to the cold are on the rise.

articles.title: As Erosion and Floods Swallow Buildings, Washington's Coastal Communities Strain to Adapt
articles.author: Claire Carlson
articles.summary: Connie Allen and David Cottrell built a cobble berm on the beach in North Cove, Washington, to stop the erosion of the shoreline. The area is at risk of coastal flooding due to climate change and other human activity. The group sold t-shirts to raise money to build the berm.

articles.title: Climate Facts: Ocean-based solutions can reduce greenhouse emissions by 35%
articles.author: Janefrances Chibundu
articles.summary: The Cable's quick climate facts will help demystify these concepts. Human-caused environmental change has intensified Atlantic hurricanes over the past six years. Ocean-based climate solutions can lower annual greenhouse gas emissions by 35 percent in 2050. UNEP says reducing emissions is the fastest, most cost-effective way to slow global warming.

articles.title: Climate Change Impacts HIV Prevention and Care: A Growing Concern
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Toronto researchers have uncovered significant insights into the interplay between climate change and health, particularly in the realm of HIV prevention and care. They found a correlation between severe weather incidents and diminished HIV prevention efforts. Extreme weather events create psychological and social stress that can lead to behaviors increasing the risk of HIV transmission. The authors advocate for the integration of disaster preparedness into HIV care frameworks.

articles.title: Winters in Great Lakes region have been shrinking by two or more weeks since 1995
articles.author: Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
articles.summary: Winters on the Great Lakes are getting shorter. Since 1995, winter has shortened by about 14 days and in some places close to three weeks. The study adds to mounting evidence that winter is the most rapidly changing season in the region, growing warmer and wetter with less snow. The biggest drop in winter days occurred in Lakes Superior and Erie, which has lost close to 3 weeks of winter. Lake Superior gained fall days and Lake Michigan gained spring days.

articles.title: Climate change washing away cherished Nova Scotia artifacts
articles.summary: Climate change is washing away places, buildings and artifacts along Nova Scotia's coastline. Some say efforts to preserve local history are a losing battle. Erin Pottie reports on the issue for CBC Radio One's "This is Life with Erin" tonight at 8 p.m. ET.

articles.title: Last year was the hottest in Brazil since 1961
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest for Brazil since 1961, according to Agencia Brasil. The weather agency Inmet found a rising trend in average annual temperatures. The agency also highlighted the influence of the recent El Niño phenomenon, from strong to very strong in 2023 and the early months of 2024.

articles.title: Climate Change Tied to Decline in HIV Care and Prevention
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New challenges in HIV prevention and care are emerging due to climate change, according to a review published earlier this month in Current Opinions in Infectious Disease. Extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding, were associated with poorer HIV prevention outcomes, including reduced HIV testing and increased practices that elevate HIV risk. The study also uncovered important implications for HIV care among those already living with HIV.

articles.title: Addressing the gendered double burden of the climate crisis
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: COP29 concluded with mixed outcomes. The issue of embedding gender-responsive strategies into climate actions remains a pressing challenge. Women in climate-vulnerable regions face what we term a "double burden" because they are poor and have few resources.

articles.title: Survey reveals Islanders' beliefs on climate change
articles.author: Stephen Blease
articles.summary: Islanders think climate change is happening, according to the latest Island Global Research survey. More than half of Islanders believe that humans are to blame for climate change. However, scepticism about climate change has grown in the past five years.    There is more doubt over whether Jersey will be affected by climate change now or in the near future.

articles.title: Why does Donald Trump want to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America?
articles.summary: Donald Trump proposes renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the 'Gulf of America' in a press conference at Mar-a-Lago on Tuesday. The Gulf is an important maritime hub, rich in natural resources, tourism, and commerce. The International Hydrographic Organisation oversees the naming of seas, oceans, and navigable waters. Renaming a body of water would require international consensus.

articles.title: Met office predicts multiple cold waves in January
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Temperatures in Dhaka and Jashore recorded their lowest temperatures of 16.3°C and 12.8°C respectively on Wednesday (Jan 8). Dense fog and chilly winds have already disrupted daily life in Bangladesh. Several cold waves are expected to sweep across the country this January.

articles.title: Cold waves loom as dense fog grips Bangladesh
articles.summary: Temperatures in Dhaka dropped to 16.3°C on Wednesday, while Jashore recorded 12.8°C. Dense fog and chilly winds have already disrupted daily life in Bangladesh. Cold waves are expected to sweep across the country, with minimum temperature as low as 4°C in some regions.

articles.title: BOM warns of wet summer saying 2025 ‘likely' to be a La Nina year
articles.author: Sarah Keszler
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology climate scientists' report warns of a La Nina event in 2025. La Nina is a climate event associated with higher-than-average rainfall over much of Australia. Australia has remained in a neutral climate condition for the past six months. Global sea surface temperatures remain above average.

articles.title: Cyclone Freddy scars yet to heal
articles.author: Barbara Kachinangwa
articles.summary: Weather experts forecasted Malawi to receive above-normal rainfall with potential flooding in 2024. However, the early warnings spelled doom and gloom for people stuck in lowlands and highlands where Cyclone Freddy dumped devastating mudslides, floods and strong winds in March 2023. 679 people lost their lives and 538 are still missing. The majority of the affected population are still grappling with its devastating aftermath. The Soche Hill disaster was neither the first nor the last.

articles.title: Greenland Explainer
articles.author: 밸류파인더 Ir 탐방노트
articles.summary: An iceberg floats in the Scoresby Sund, on Sept. 12, 2023, in Greenland, according to Chris Szagola of the Associated Press. The iceberg was caused by a heavy downpouring of water from the north Atlantic Ocean. The cause of the downpour was not immediately clear.

articles.title: Resource-rich Greenland plays key role in a warming world
articles.summary: Donald Trump has expressed interest in acquiring Greenland. Greenland is a semiautonomous territory of Denmark, a longtime U.S. ally and a founding member of NATO. The region is warming four times faster than the rest of the globe. Greenland has valuable rare earth minerals, uranium, billions of untapped barrels of oil and natural gas. Greenland also serves as the engine and on/off switch for a key ocean current that influences Earth's climate.

articles.title: Norfolk and Suffolk councils to split over coastal project
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: Great Yarmouth Borough Council, North Norfolk District Council and East Suffolk Council have worked together under the guise of Coastal Partnership East to manage 100 miles of vulnerable coast since 2016. The aim of the scheme was to pool resources to better tackle the threat of climate change and coastal erosion. However, enthusiasm for the partnership has waned and it now appears likely that the three authorities will go their separate ways.

articles.title: Flagship coastal project enters choppy waters as councils clash
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: Coastal Partnership East has helped to protect Norfolk and Suffolk's coastline for nearly a decade. The three councils involved in the project are at loggerheads over its future. The aim of the scheme was to pool resources to better tackle the threat of climate change and coastal erosion. It is not thought ending the partnership will affect the councils' ability to get funding from the Environment Agency.

articles.title: Flagship coastal project enters choppy waters as councils clash
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: East Suffolk Council has agreed to dissolve the Coastal Partnership East. Great Yarmouth Borough Council, North Norfolk District Council and East Suffolk Council will decide later this month if they want to continue with the project. The aim of the scheme was to pool resources to better tackle the threat of climate change and coastal erosion.

articles.title: Norfolk and Suffolk councils to split over coastal project
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: East Suffolk Council has agreed to dissolve the Coastal Partnership East. Great Yarmouth Borough Council, North Norfolk District Council and East Suffolk Council will decide later this month if they want to continue with the project. The aim of the scheme was to pool resources to better tackle the threat of climate change and coastal erosion.

articles.title: Greenland: The Icy Heart of Global Climate Politics
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Greenland's vast icy landscape is at the forefront of global geopolitics and climate conversations. The melting ice sheet poses a threat to global sea levels but also holds untapped natural resources that the world covets. The island remains a focal point of interest due to its rare minerals, potential oil reserves and significant geopolitical location.

articles.title: Earth Rotation Day being observed today
articles.summary: Earth Rotation Day is being observed globally today (Wednesday). The day celebrates the rotation of planet earth on its axis which is crucial for defining time and shape of life. Earth rotates at a speed of approximately 1,670 km per hour at the equator. It takes roughly 24 hours for Earth to complete one full rotation.

articles.title: Localities urged to prepare for intense cold wave
articles.author: SGGP

The Gulf of Tonkin, the Central and Southern regions of the East Sea, and coastal areas from Quang Tri to Khanh Hoa will strengthen blustery winds, rough seas and huge waves. Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development urges localities to take preventive measures.

articles.title: Climate Advisory Team unveils policy recommendations, hosting virtual presentation Friday
articles.summary: The Climate Advisory Team, established by Hawai'i Governor Josh Green, M.D., in May 2024, has released its policy paper. It includes recommendations to inform the administration's legislative priorities for the 2025 legislative session and beyond. The team conducted extensive research to understand the unique challenges faced and glean insights into potential policy solutions.

articles.title: Physics Behind March 2022 Flash Floods Unveiled
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: There was a flash flood in Nusantara, Indonesia on March 15-16, 2022. Mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) were the main cause of the heavy rainfall. Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) and equatorial waves played a significant role in the development of MCSs. Local factors, such as small-scale convection, local evaporation, land-surface feedback, and topography, also played a role in modulating the intensity and duration of the MCS.

articles.title: Trees crash into Pasadena apartments and house due to wind
articles.author: Sydney Barragan
articles.summary: High winds have caused damage across Los Angeles County due to the worst winds in over a decade, said to be the worst in over 10 years, according to the weather service. The damage is estimated to be around $1 billion.

articles.title: 2024 temperatures among highest on record
articles.author: Katie Todd
articles.summary: New Zealand's temperatures were above average for eight months of last year, making it the country's 10th hottest year on record. March and May were the only two months that recorded below-average temperatures. Blenheim was the sunniest spot in the country, recording 2769 hours of sunshine. Lumsden observed its wettest year since records began, with 1249mm of rain.

articles.title: Last year's temperatures among top 10 on record
articles.author: Katie Todd
articles.summary: New Zealand's temperatures were above average for eight months of last year, making it the country's tenth hottest year on record. March and May were the only two months that recorded below-average temperatures. Blenheim was the sunniest spot in the country, recording 2769 hours of sunshine. Lumsden observed its wettest year since records began in 1982, with 1249mm of rain.

articles.title: NZ's 10th warmest year on record: What we can learn from 2024 climate data
articles.author: Katie Todd
articles.summary: New Zealand's temperatures were above average for eight months of last year, making it the country's tenth hottest year on record. March and May were the only two months that recorded below-average temperatures. Blenheim was the sunniest spot in the country, recording 2769 hours of sunshine. Lumsden observed its wettest year since records began in 1982, with 1249mm of rain. Dargaville and Whitianga had their driest years on record with just 72 percent and 66 percent of their normal annual rainfall.

articles.title: NIWA Annual Climate Summary 2024
articles.author: Act New Zealand
articles.summary: 2024 was Aotearoa New Zealand's 10th-warmest year on record. The average temperature was 13.25C, 0.51C above the 1991-2020 annual average. December and January were the country's warmest months compared to normal, while May and March were relatively cool. Several extreme rainfall events occurred throughout the year, with four local state of emergency declarations. The southern South Island was exposed to frequent rain-bearing systems during the year.

articles.title: Japan's hottest year: record breaking temperatures threaten rice supply
articles.author: Julian Ryall
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year since data collection began in 1898. The average temperature was 1.48 degrees Celsius above the mean for the 30-year period ending in 2020. Monthly records were broken in April, July, and October, while summer temperatures tied the highs of 2023. Tokyo hit 30.1 degrees Celsius on October 19.

articles.title: November headline inflation climbs to 2.3 per cent
articles.summary: Australia's headline inflation has risen to 2.3 per cent for the month of November, according to the latest data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The inflation rate has risen from 2.2 per cent in October and 2.1 per cent a month earlier.

articles.summary: Home insurance premiums are going up due to climate change and more frequent natural disasters. The cost of claims related to natural disasters in Canada has tripled in the last decade. Squamish-Lillooet Regional District has been implementing the FireSmart program since 2020. FireSmart offers free home assessments, clean-up days, and financial rebates to help homeowners reduce wildfire risks. The District also invested in building bigger dikes, upgrading infrastructure, and investing in wildfire preparedness.

articles.title: Since November, a warm weather pattern has dominated winter in Anchorage
articles.author: Alaska Public Media
articles.summary: Winter rain has caused icy conditions across much of Southcentral Alaska. It led to school closures and delays from the Kenai Peninsula through Anchorage and up to the Mat-Su Borough. On Monday, Anchorage hit a record high temperature of 42 degrees, a degree warmer than the previous record for this date set in 2014. Alaska is currently in a La Niña weather pattern, which typically means cooler northerly systems coming through the state.
